newsitem.title: USA: FULL TEXT - Oracle reports Q1 results.
newsitem.headline: FULL TEXT - Oracle reports Q1 results.

text.p: Oracle Corp Thursday reported first quarter results. The following is a copy of the company's news release.

REDWOOD SHORES, Calif., Sept. 12 /PRNewswire/ -- Oracle Corporation (Nasdaq: ORCL) today announced record first quarter results for the quarter ended August 31, 1996. Revenues increased 36 percent to $1.052 billion from $772 million in the same period last year. Net income for the period increased 110 percent to $113 million, or $0.17 per share, compared to net income of $54 million, or $0.08 per share, in the first quarter of fiscal 1996, which included the $34 million after-tax charge for the purchase of in-process research and development from Information Resources, Inc. in the same period last year.

First quarter license sales grew by 27 percent year-to-year (26 percent when combined with other revenues). Database license revenue led overall license growth at 41%, confirming the continued strong demand for Oracle(R) Universal Server(R), Oracle's core technology. Oracle Services (Support, Consulting and Education) grew 45%.

Geographically, Oracle reported solid performance worldwide, despite a 3 percentage point negative currency translation during the first quarter, with Asia/Pacific heavily impacted by a weaker yen. Oracle Americas reported the strongest revenue growth geographically at 43% versus the same period last year.
Oracle made a number of significant announcements during the first fiscal quarter of 1997:

* Oracle outlined its intranet strategy to deliver the industry's first comprehensive product line that enables full-service intranets. This platform enables the full-service intranet for the first time by helping corporations build real applications, conduct Web transactions, easily manage corporate Web information, and minimize information overload. Products include:
-- Oracle7.3, the world's most popular database,
-- Oracle Web Server 2.0, the first Web server to support next generation intranet applications,
-- Designer/2000, Developer/2000 and Oracle Power Objects, for client server application development and HTML application deployment,
-- Oracle InterOffice, the only fully scalable, web-based collaboration software,
-- Oracle Applications for the Web, version 2.0, a new family of self-service applications providing extensive new functionality targeted for enterprise intranets.

* Oracle announced the successful rollout of Oracle(R) Universal Server(R) with Oracle7 Release 7.3 which began shipping in March of this year and has been adopted by hundreds of companies, government organizations and leading institutions worldwide. Preparing for the next major step with Oracle(R) Universal Server(R), Oracle has achieved its first key milestone for Oracle8, which entered beta testing in August. Over 300 partners and representatives have been trained on the beta product, which will undergo intensive testing before moving into general availability.

* Oracle's Developer/2000 and Designer/2000 continue to win top honors in key product surveys. The June InfoWorld review found that Developer/2000 delivered the most robust performance and features for mission-critical applications. Also, in Computerworld's 1996 Application Development Tool Brand Preference Survey, Developer/2000 won for "best technology," "best service and support," "best documentation," and the "preferred company to do business with," while Designer/2000, Oracle's generation and modeling tool, swept all seven CASE categories.

* Oracle's database and warehousing solutions beat Informix and Sybase as its flagship Oracle7 relational database was honored with awards for "Best Database Server Software" and "Best Data Warehousing Product" in Databased Advisor Magazine's annual Readers' Choice Awards. Polling over 125,000 readers, Databased Advisor asked them to choose the products that provided the best tools for building powerful business solutions.

* Oracle announced their roadmap for delivering its core products on the Microsoft Windows NT 4.0 operating system including Oracle7, Oracle WebServer, application development tools, collaboration products, packaged applications, OLAP products and middleware. These announcements extended Oracle's commitment to the Windows NT platform, which started two years ago when Oracle became the first major information management company to make its database available on Windows NT.

"The continued strength in our server performance affirms the need for powerful technology in the new market of network computing," said Raymond J. Lane, Oracle's President and Chief Operating Officer. "As the world expands its need for client server computing, Oracle is providing a stack of technology, applications and services capable of responding to these requirements."

Oracle Corp. is the world's second largest software company, and the largest supplier of software for information management. With annual revenues of more than $4.5 billion, the company offers its database, tools and application products, along with related consulting, education, and support services, in more than 90 countries around the world.
